meanings.def: to fire a gun or other weapon; to fire something from a weapon
examples: Don't shoot—I surrender.
The police rarely shoot to kill (= try to kill the people they shoot at).
The soldiers were given orders to shoot on sight (= as soon as they saw somebody).
shoot at somebody/something troops shooting at the enemy
shoot something Have you ever shot a gun before?
They shot the lock off (= removed it by shooting).
shoot something at somebody/something She shot a bullet right at me but missed.
shoot something from something He shot an arrow from his bow.
The laundry chute leads down to the washer-dryer area in the basement.
The recruits are learning to shoot at targets.
She posed for the cameras as though for a fashion shoot.
I thought for a moment that he was going to shoot.
She practised for days until she could shoot straight.
If they shoot, we shoot back.
The soldiers shot back at invading planes with rifles.
The soldiers were shooting at a target.
They began shooting at the enemy.
Troops shot into the air to stop the rioting.
a shoot-to-kill policy

meanings.def: to kill or wound a person or an animal with a bullet, etc.
examples: shoot somebody/something/yourself He shot himself during a fit of depression.
shoot somebody/something/yourself in something He was left brain-damaged after being shot in the head.
They were shot in the back while trying to escape.
A man was shot in the leg.
shoot somebody/something/yourself with something In the struggle the burglar was shot with his own gun.
Four policemen were fatally shot during the incident.
Three people were shot dead during the robbery.
Forty people a day are shot and killed in this country.
She was shot to death for a crime she did not commit.
Any intruders will be shot on sight.
He accidentally shot himself in the foot.
If caught, the men could be summarily shot as spies.
He was shot at close range.

meanings.def: to fire bullets, etc.
examples: Does this gun actually shoot?
shoot something This is just a toy gun—it doesn't shoot real bullets.

meanings.def: to hunt and kill birds and animals with a gun as a sport
examples: to shoot pheasants
They go shooting in Scotland.

meanings.def: to make a film or photograph of something
examples: Cameras ready? OK, shoot!
shoot something to shoot a film/video/scene
The film crew returned to the area to shoot more footage.
I managed to shoot a photo of the elephants before they disappeared into the trees.
shoot something + adv./prep. Where was the movie shot?
The movie was shot in black and white.
The film is beautifully shot and edited.
The film was shot on location in Death Valley.

meanings.def: to move suddenly or quickly in one direction; to make somebody/something move in this way
examples: + adv./prep. A plane shot across the sky.
Her hand shot out to grab my wrist.
Flames were shooting up through the roof.
(figurative) The band's last single shot straight to number one in the charts.
shoot something + adv./prep. She shot out her hand to grab my wrist.
A cat shot out into the road in front of him.
I saw someone shooting past the window.

meanings.def: to move suddenly and quickly and be very sharp
examples: a shooting pain in the back
+ adv./prep. The pain shot up her arm.

meanings.def: to direct something at somebody suddenly or quickly
examples: shoot something at somebody Journalists were shooting questions at the candidates.
She shot an angry glance at him.
shoot somebody something She shot him an angry glance.
Darren shot her a filthy look.

meanings.def: to try to kick, hit or throw the ball into a goal or to score a point
examples: He should have shot instead of passing.
Marta shot wide (= missed the goal), but scored minutes later.
(especially North American English) shoot something After school we'd be on the driveway shooting hoops (= playing basketball).

meanings.def: to make a particular score in a complete round or competition
examples: She shot a 75 in the first round.

meanings.def: to play particular games
examples: to shoot pool

meanings.def: used to emphasize how easy it is to do something
examples: What do you mean you can't do it? It'll be like shooting fish in a barrel!

meanings.def: to look at somebody in a way that shows you are annoyed with them
to have used all your power, money or supplies
to have a conversation in an informal way
examples: We sat around in the bar, shooting the breeze.

meanings.def: to react quickly without thinking carefully first
to fight against somebody with guns, especially until one side is killed or defeated
examples: The gang decided to shoot it out with the police.

meanings.def: to blame the person who gives the news that something bad has happened, instead of the person who is really responsible
examples: Don't shoot the messenger!

meanings.def: to talk about something in a way that shows that you are too proud of it
to talk about something that is private or secret
to go in a boat over part of a river where the water flows very fast
to suddenly become famous, especially as a singer or actor
examples: He shot to fame almost overnight.
She shot to stardom in a Broadway musical.

meanings.def: to do or say something that will cause you a lot of trouble or harm, especially when you are trying to get an advantage for yourself

idioms.idiom: be like shooting fish in a barrel
idioms.def: used to emphasize how easy it is to do something
examples: What do you mean you can't do it? It'll be like shooting fish in a barrel!

idioms.def: to look at somebody in a way that shows you are annoyed with them
to have used all your power, money or supplies
to have a conversation in an informal way
examples: We sat around in the bar, shooting the breeze.

idioms.def: to react quickly without thinking carefully first
to fight against somebody with guns, especially until one side is killed or defeated
examples: The gang decided to shoot it out with the police.

idioms.def: to blame the person who gives the news that something bad has happened, instead of the person who is really responsible
examples: Don't shoot the messenger!

idioms.def: to talk about something in a way that shows that you are too proud of it
to go in a boat over part of a river where the water flows very fast
to suddenly become famous, especially as a singer or actor
examples: He shot to fame almost overnight.
She shot to stardom in a Broadway musical.

idioms.def: to do or say something that will cause you a lot of trouble or harm, especially when you are trying to get an advantage for yourself

meanings.def: the part that grows up from the ground when a plant starts to grow; a new part that grows on plants or trees
examples: new green shoots
bamboo shoots
Keep the bulbs in a cool dark place until shoots appear.
These shrubs will need more light to produce flowering shoots.
This plant has no shoots yet.

meanings.def: an occasion when somebody takes professional photographs for a particular purpose or makes a film
examples: a fashion shoot
The laundry chute leads down to the washer-dryer area in the basement.
The recruits are learning to shoot at targets.
She posed for the cameras as though for a fashion shoot.
He goes out on shoots with very little equipment.
a cover shoot for the September issue of Cosmopolitan

meanings.def: an occasion when a group of people hunt and shoot animals or birds for sport; the land where this happens
examples: He was shot in the face while on a game shoot.

meanings.def: used to show that you are annoyed when you do something stupid or when something goes wrong (to avoid saying ‘shit’)
examples: Shoot! I've forgotten my book!

meanings.def: used to tell somebody to say what they want to say
examples: You want to tell me something? OK, shoot!
